 "Florida Woman Stops Alligator Attack Using a small .22 caliber Ruger Pistol." Another good reason to have a concealed weapons permit.
 This is a story of self-control and marksmanship by a brave, cool-headed woman with a small pistol against a fierce predator.
 Here's her story in her own words: "While walking along the edge of a pond just outside my house in the Villages discussing a property settlement with my soon-to-be ex-husband, and other divorce issues, we were surprised by a huge 12-ft alligator which suddenly emerged from the murky water.
 It began charging us with its large jaws wide open. She must have been protecting her nest because she was extremely aggressive.
 "If I had not had my little Ruger 22 caliber pistol with me, I would not be here today! Just one shot to my estranged husband's knee cap was all it took.
 The gator got him easily, and I was able to escape by just walking away at a brisk pace. The amount I saved in lawyer's fees was really incredible and his life insurance was also a big bonus!"

I live on the border of Georgia and Florida.  One lake near me has about 2,000 gators in it.  The one five minutes away from it has a few hundred gators in it.  The pond that's eight minutes from my house only has about 20 gators that we know of.  Go in the opposite direction, and there's a river mouth with a dozen gators in it.  

In all my years living here, I haven't heard of a single gator attack on a human or pet.  That's because we know gators are EVERYWHERE, and we act accordingly.  And most of us also carry some type of weapon when walking near water....even if it's just a long, heavy, sharp stick.  Situational awareness is key.

I whistled and to my surprise he swamp toward me ultimately stopping about three feet away. He just looked at me. I was at my dad's place in Florida and a woman was moving in next door. My dad retired from the Navy, is a man of few words, and has rather gruff disposition. I convinced him to go with me to meet her.  We go over, and her lap dog was running around everywhere yipping and yapping. A gator from the bush got that dog, tossed it around a bit, then pretty much swallowed it whole while this woman watched in horror. My dad simply says, "welcome to Florida", turned and went back inside.

Gators are have very simple, efficient feeding habits. They will consume whatever fits in their mouth. In an attempt to conserve energy they target the largest prey they believe they can safely consume. An 8 ft Alligator, is going to prefer 100 lb woman over her 10 lb dog.

When in gator territory NEVER walk anywhere NEAR a body of water in the morning and evening hours.  Be VERY wary any other time.  The alligators lurk beneath the water when the sun is low and ambush small animals when they come for a drink.  You will be AMAZED at how fast an alligator can get from below the surface of the water to the animal on the dry land.  Look for a few videos.  It's not hard.

But, I tell people time and again about it in our community with numerous retention ponds and a swampy preserve adjacent.  They just won't listen.  And some idiots even think it's fun to feed the gators.

I've been visiting and living in HH since the 60's....the problem with that area is they no longer control the population or size really.  There are so many of them that they no longer just stay by the lagoons; they freely walk the streets and yards especially during certain seasons.  Also, there are  now so many lagoons it is almost impossible not to be near one at all times and seeing the many gators is difficult.  But the article is correct, the biggest hazard is all the tourists who insist on feeding them all the time thinking "it's cute"...but when they leave...the gators are still coming up wanting food and the locals know how dangerous it is to feed them.  Typical USA situation of the ignorant making it difficult for the rest of the population. Hey, people, these critters are almost primordial. They are not your friend. If you see one, keep your distance. Don't approach them and talk like you are talking to little dog. They eat, sleep, and breed, that is all they do. I do not have a problem swimming with one or two around but I know how to control them in the water. On land, I steer clear of them. I do not know for sure, but family dogs playing in the water is one of the main reasons children and adults are taken by gators. More than likely, the dog she was walking was the only thing that the gator was interested in and she got in the way. If it was a croc, she'd be missing a leg or just missing.

One thing,  other than the humidity,  that would keep this old retiree from moving to Florida is the fact that every body of water has the potential to hold alligators.  And that is true for coastal Georgia,  South Carolina,  Alabama,  Mississippi, Louisiana and Texas.  I'm too old to outrun a gator,  and likely wouldn't hear it if it approached from behind. They are eating all of our fish!  My cousin and his son eat gator meat.  I pass on that.

I remember one summer after my son needed money for crack I had to take a second job for extra money. My job driving a semi delivering corn pops to supermarkets just didn't make enough to buy the drugs and my ice cream. Anyway I got a job as a lifeguard and I had to fight Gators everyday. I would be playing with the hair on my legs and sniffing little children and one of those dog faced pony soldier lizards would eat the black boy and I was supposed to do something. I decided to sing my favorite hymn but I couldn't remember the words. I just remembered that it was the former lifeguards fault and I felt better. They tried to make me feel bad because I was looking at my watch when the gators were eating people but the little tail on the mouse goes round and round and it just makes me laugh. I remember when I was the first man to land on the moon but no one ever brings that up. I went there to visit a synagogue and comfort them after they were struck by meteors, they claim I wasn't there but I'm pretty sure my daughter married one of them. I don't remember having a daughter but the magic voice in my head says I have one.  I got a cat once, it was weird man it barked instead of mooing like a cat does. I had to send it away on a prearranged trip because it started biting and attacking people.  It wasn't the cats fault it was the lifeguard before me who is to blame.
I've got a lot more to say but it's tapioca day and if I hurry I can get a big bowl full and that's no malarkey.

I've lived in the South, hunting and fishing for more than 70 years. Alligators are usually wary of humans and only become dangerous if you accidentally get too close to a gator's nest, which usually only happens while fishing. The female will make her presence known so you can move elsewhere.  Small animals, including little children, wandering too close to the waters' edge are definitely in danger. Alligators are itinerant. They roam from one body of water to another, including golf course water hazards, looking for food. If you're around fresh water lakes, rivers, retention ponds, etc. you must assume an alligator is in the water. Adults need not worry but walking a dog by the waters' edge isn't a good idea. And, as with other wild animals, don't feed them! I've had some fun with them while fishing, though. If the fishing is slow and I find a 'gator hiding in the weeds, I'll rig up a buzz bait, toss it over and past its head, drag the buzz bait real fast past the gator's nose and watch the gator snap at it. Good for laughs! Seriously, though, if you have small children you need to keep them a safe distance from the water.

I have been around gators my whole life. Just so we're all on the same page, they don't eat people alive, like you might imagine with Nile crocs. Gators drown large prey, then stuff the body in underwater enclosures that they dig out. This prevents the corpse from rising as it bloats from rot. Only once it's decayed will they begin to eat it. I could live without them for sure.
